awd_titl_txt: EAGER/Collaborative Research: High-throughput, Autonomous Real-time Monitoring of Tissue Mechanical Property Change via Impedimetric Sensor Arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will support research to improve engineered tissues. Engineered tissues have become important platforms for the development of therapeutics for many diseases and disorders. They hold particular promise for improving wound healing. Cells sense and respond their environment. How they sense their environment effects how they form tissues. How a cell's local environment affects it's behavior during wound healing is still not well understood. There have been substantial strides that have been made in the use of engineered tissues for disease modeling and drug development. However, simultaneously monitoring cellular behavior and tissue properties remains a challenge, and limits further advances. This project will create autonomous tissue culture monitoring platforms that enable real-time monitoring of multi-scale cellular behavior and tissue properties. If successful, scalable and high-throughput methods for autonomous monitoring of engineered tissues will be realized. This could have profound and broad socioeconomic benefits in terms of public health and drug discovery. The project will engage students through research experiences for undergraduates in data acquisition for autonomous life sciences research. 

The goal of this project is to advance the ability to simultaneously quantify the dynamic multi-scale attributes of engineered tissues in real time. The central approach is to establish the feasibility of a novel autonomous sensor-based experimental platform for dynamically quantifying bulk extracellular matrix (ECM) mechanical properties, multi-cellular anatomical structures, cell phenotypes, and gene and protein expression during wound healing processes using sensor-integrated 3D cell culture models. The work involves the following research objectives: 1) to utilize a cantilever sensor-integrated well plate format for autonomous monitoring of a fibroblast-Schwann cell 3D co-culture model treated with exogenous transforming growth factor (TGF-β) to invoke a wound healing response, and 2) to compare real-time changes in bulk ECM mechanical properties with temporal changes in gene and protein expression levels in 3D co-culture models. This work will yield the first quantitative description of the dynamic relationship between real-time ECM mechanical changes and cell behaviors in tissues undergoing wound healing. The project also provides research experiences for undergraduate students in data acquisition for autonomous tissue characterization and bioprocess monitoring.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia

por.por_cntn:
This project, funded by an Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER)), aimed to enhance the understanding of engineered tissues, particularly in wound healing, by continuously monitoring tissue mechanical properties using integrated sensors. Recognizing that the interplay between cellular behavior and their local environment is critical to tissue formation, the project set out to create an innovative autonomous monitoring platform capable of simultaneously quantifying multi-scale cellular behavior and tissue attributes (e.g., properties) in real time. This report outlines the project's intellectual merit, significant outcomes, and broader impacts.

The project established new technology for 3D cell culture monitoring in the form of cantilever sensor-integrated well plate formats that facilitate real-time monitoring of 3D cell culture mechanical properties. An equivalent circuit model was established to aid in designing and calibrating sensor arrays based on impedimetric sensing. Supporting hardware, software, and protocols were created to extend the technology's use in applications requiring chronic monitoring over extended times and in extreme environments that limit human interaction with the cell culture platform, such as space applications. The technology this project established offers the potential to observe changes in bulk tissue properties associated with changes in cellular behavior in real time. Thus, the technology may be applied to the development of new and improved therapeutics for wound healing. Controlled and enhanced wound healing is critical for patient recovery and a significant aspect of several diseases and disorders, and it can significantly reduce healthcare costs and improve quality of life. This project lays the groundwork for further exploration into the dynamic interactions between cellular environments and behaviors.

In conclusion, this project represents an advancement in technology for studying engineered tissues in practical cell culture formats. Through innovative methodologies and a commitment to educational engagement, the project has produced valuable insights into wound-healing processes and established a foundation for future research and public health advancements. The successful amalgamation of technology and biological research highlights the interdisciplinary nature of modern scientific inquiry and underlines the potential socioeconomic benefits of such work.

We encourage future investigations to explore applications to other 3D cell culture models and applications to expand the understanding of tissue responses across different environments. Continuous collaboration with industry partners, such as in biomanufacturing or biomedical domains, can enhance the translational potential of the findings and promote real-world applications. This project also demonstrated the importance of sustained interdisciplinary training in biotechnology to develop a skilled workforce in biomanufacturing and regenerative medicine. This summary encapsulates the project's achievements, underscoring its intellectual merit and broader impacts on society and the scientific community.

 


Last Modified: 01/08/2025
Modified by: Shayn Peirce-Cottler
